translationKeys.customInstructions: Use snake_case for keypath names. Follow existing structure patterns (e.g., common.app.name, common.actions.submit).

ai.translationsCustomInstructions: Prefer informal tone. Use sentence case for titles. Keep technical terms in English when they are industry standards.

translationsCustomInstructionsPerLocale.en-US: Use clear, concise English. Prefer active voice.
translationsCustomInstructionsPerLocale.es-ES: Use 'tú' (informal) instead of 'usted' (formal). Keep technical terms in English when standard.
translationsCustomInstructionsPerLocale.fr-FR: Use 'tu' (informal) instead of 'vous' (formal). Keep technical terms in English when commonly used.
translationsCustomInstructionsPerLocale.de-DE: Use informal 'du' instead of formal 'Sie'. Keep technical terms in English when commonly used.
translationsCustomInstructionsPerLocale.it-IT: Use 'tu' (informal) instead of 'Lei' (formal). Keep technical terms in English when standard.
translationsCustomInstructionsPerLocale.pt-BR: Use 'você' (informal). Keep technical terms in English when commonly used.
translationsCustomInstructionsPerLocale.el-GR: Use informal 'εσύ' (esy). Keep technical terms in English when commonly used.

global: Keep brand names untranslated and lowercased (e.g., 'matlab', 'samsung', 'iphone', 'android')
Keep technical terms in English when they are industry standards (e.g., 'AI', 'API', 'JSON', 'HTTP', 'REST')
Keep product names and model numbers untranslated (e.g., 'iPhone 15 Pro', 'Galaxy S24')
Keep mathematical and scientific terms in English when they are universal (e.g., 'Deep Learning', 'Neural Network', 'Machine Learning')
Keep file extensions and formats untranslated (e.g., '.json', '.csv', '.png', '.webp')
Keep version numbers and technical specifications as-is (e.g., 'v3.0', '5G', 'Wi-Fi 6')
Use lowercase for brand names in translations (e.g., 'matlab analytics' not 'MATLAB Analytics')
Maintain consistent terminology across all locales for technical concepts

de: Use informal 'du' instead of formal 'Sie' throughout the application
Use 'Sie' only in error messages or critical system notifications
Keep technical terms in English when they are commonly used in German tech context
Use German technical terms when they are more commonly used (e.g., 'Smartphone' instead of 'Mobiltelefon')
es: Use 'tú' (informal) instead of 'usted' (formal) for user-facing text
Use 'usted' only in formal error messages or legal text
Keep brand names and technical terms in English when they are industry standard
Use Spanish technical terms when appropriate (e.g., 'teléfono inteligente' for 'smartphone')
fr: Use 'tu' (informal) instead of 'vous' (formal) for user interactions
Use 'vous' only in formal contexts or error messages
Keep technical terms in English when they are commonly used in French tech context
Use French technical terms when they are standard (e.g., 'téléphone intelligent' for 'smartphone')
it: Use 'tu' (informal) instead of 'Lei' (formal) for user-facing content
Use 'Lei' only in formal error messages
Keep technical terms in English when they are industry standard
Use Italian technical terms when appropriate
pt: Use 'você' (informal) instead of 'o senhor/a senhora' (formal) for user interactions
Use formal address only in error messages or legal text
Keep technical terms in English when they are commonly used
Use Portuguese technical terms when standard
el: Use informal 'εσύ' (esy) instead of formal 'εσείς' (eseis) for user interactions
Use formal address only in error messages or system notifications
Keep technical terms in English when they are commonly used in Greek tech context
Use Greek technical terms when appropriate
